title:
Sampling Theorem and explicit interpolation formula for non-decaying
  unbounded signals

sections.text:
#### Abstract

The paper establishes an analog Whittaker-Shannon-Kotelnikov sampling theorem for unbounded non-decaying band-limited signals. An explicit interpolation formula is obtained for signals sublinear growth with rate of growth less than $1 / 2$. At any time, the rate of decay for the $k$ th coefficients of this formula is $\sim 1 / k^{2}$. In addition, the paper obtains a method for calculating the coefficients of the interpolation formula applicable to signals with arbitrarily high rate of polynomial growth.


Keywords: continuous time signals, interpolation, Sampling Theorem, Whittaker-ShannonKotelnikov interpolation formula, unbounded signals, non-decaying signals, band-limited signals,

## 1 Introduction

Problems of recovery of signals from incomplete observations were studied intensively in different settings. This includes recovering signals from samples. It is known that smooth signals can be recovered arbitrarily small error from samples taken with sufficient frequency. This lead to the interpolation problem. There are many different approaches to this problem for smooth enough signals: splines, B-splines, or mean values of signal between sampling points; see, e.g., $[1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,10,14,16,20,21]$, and the references therein. In particular, B-spline methods have been applied for multi-dimension signals featuring polynomial growth, including the case defined on multidimensional spaces $[1,2,16,20,21]$.

In this paper, we focus on interpolation formulae such as

$$
x(t)=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} a_{k}(t) x(k)
$$

where $t \in \mathbf{R}, x: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ is a signal, $a_{k}(t)$ are some coefficients.
For the Schwartz space of rapidly decaying functions, there is an interpolation formula [22]. The coefficients of this formula have to be calculated via numerical integration of some special function, so it can be called semi-explicit; see also [23]. This formula includes the value of the Fourier transforms at the sampling points.

For the band-limited signals vanishing on $\pm \infty$, there is an interpolation formula with explicitly given coefficients: the classical Nyquist-Shannon sampling theorem establishes that a band-limited signal can be recovered without error from a discrete sample taken with a sampling rate that is at least twice the maximum frequency of the signal (the Nyquist critical rate). In particular, a band-limited signal $x(\cdot) \in L_{2}(\mathbf{R})$ with the support of the Fourier transform $\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-i \omega s} x(s) d s$ contained in the interval $[-\pi, \pi]$ can be recovered from its sample $\{x(k)\}_{k=-\infty}^{\infty}$ as

$$
x(t)=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\sin (\pi(k-t))}{\pi(k-t)} x(k)
$$

This is celebrated Whittaker-Shannon-Kotelnikov interpolation formula, also known as Whittaker-Shannon interpolation formula, Shannon's interpolation formula, and Whittaker's interpolation formula. It can be observed that since the coefficients of this interpolation formula are decreasing as $\sim 1 / k$, it covers only signals such that $x(t) \rightarrow 0$ with a certain rate as $|t| \rightarrow+\infty$.

There are many works devoted to generalization of the Sampling Theorem; see e.g. the reviews in $[13,15,19,25,27,28]$ and literature therein. Unfortunately, the generalisations listed therein do not lead to any alternative explicit interpolation formulae for standard band-limited signals from $L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$, and they not cover the setting with non-decaying signals.

As far as we know, there are only one another explicit interpolation formulae in the existing literature: it is Vaaler formula [26]; see some analysis in [23]. This formula is different from (1) since it includes the value of derivatives at the sampling points. The coefficients of this formula decay as $\sim 1 / k$, similarly to (2).

The present paper obtains interpolation formulae similar to (2) but with faster decreasing coefficients. This itself is a useful feature, since it allows to reduce the error caused by truncation that is unavoidable in calculations. However, the main focus of this paper is extension of the

interpolation formula on unbounded and non-vanishing band-limited signals. Let us explain why it is important. It can be observed that a unbounded non-vanishing signal usually can be modified to a signal from $L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$ without any loss of information, for example, by replacement a signal $x(t)$ featuring polynomial growth by $e^{-|t|} x(t)$. However, at least for the case of signals from $L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$, these damping transformations represent the convolutions in the frequency domain, with smoothing kernels. Unfortunately, a band-limited signal will be transformed into a non-bandlimited one along the way. For the general type unbounded two-sided processes, one could expect a similar impact of the damping transformations on the spectrum. Therefore, it was essential to develop a special approach for obtaining explicit interpolation formulae applicable to unbounded non-decaying signals $x$ featuring polynomial growth such that

$$
\sup _{t \in \mathbf{R}}(1+|t|)^{-\alpha}|x(t)|<+\infty
$$

for some $\alpha \geq 0$.
The paper obtains an analog of Sampling Theorem and a interpolation formula (1) for bandlimited non-decaying one-dimensional unbounded signals featuring polynomial growth and such that their spectrum is contained in a interval $I \subset(-\pi, \pi)$. We show that, for these signals, where the series absolutely converge for each $t \in \mathbf{R}$. The coefficients in (1) are calculated as

$$
a_{k}(t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} E(t, \omega) e^{-i \omega k} d \omega
$$

for some regular enough functions $E(t, \omega): \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ such that $E(t, \omega)=e^{i \omega t}$ for $\omega \in I$ (Theorem 4.2). The requirements for the regularity of these function are defined by the allowed rate of growth for a class of admissible signals $x$. An algorithm for calculations of $a_{k}(t)$ is provided (Lemma 4.3 below). In particular, it is shown that, for any $\alpha \geq 0$, the functions $E$ can be selected such that $a_{k}(t)$ decay faster than $\sim 1 / k^{\nu}$ for some $\nu>1+\alpha$.

Furthermore, for the special case of the signals featuring sublinear growth with $\alpha \in[0,1 / 2)$, we calculated the coefficients $a_{k}(t)$ explicitly (Theorem 2.3). The $k$ th coefficients for the corresponding new interpolation formula (5) are decreasing as $\sim 1 / k^{2}$. A more general case of the signals featuring subquadratic growth with $\alpha \in[0,3 / 2)$, we found a semi-explicit representation for the coefficients $a_{k}(t)$ via integrals of functions $e^{-i \omega k} \omega^{l}$ for $l=1,2,3$. (Theorem 2.4 and formula (6) in Section 2). The corresponding $\left|a_{k}(t)\right|$ decay faster than $\sim 1 / k^{5 / 2}$. It is also shown how to construct the coefficients $a_{k}(t)$ for the general case where $\alpha \geq 3 / 2$ such that the corresponding values $a_{k}(t)$.

Some numerical experiments are described in Section 5.

# 2 The main result: Sampling theorem and interpolation formula
## Some notations

Let $\mathbf{R}$ and $\mathbf{C}$, be the set of all real and complex numbers, respectively, and let $\mathbb{Z}$ be the set of all integers.

For $r \in[1, \infty)$, we denote by $L_{r}(\mathbf{R})$ the standard space of all functions $x: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$, considered up to equivalency, such that $\|x\|_{L_{r}(\mathbf{R})}:=\left(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|x(t)|^{r} d t\right)^{1 / r}<+\infty$. We denote by $L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$ the standard space of all functions $x: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$, considered up to equivalency, such that $\|x\|_{L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})}:=$ ess $\sup _{t \in \mathbf{R}}|x(t)|<+\infty$.

We denote by $C(\mathbf{R})$ the standard linear space of continuous functions $f: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ with the uniform norm $\|f\|_{C}:=\sup _{t}|f(t)|$.

Let $\alpha>0$ be given. Let $\rho: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow(0,1]$ be defined as

$$
\rho(t)=(1+|t|)^{-\alpha}
$$

Let $\rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$ be the space of functions $f: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ such that $\rho f \in L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$, with the norm $\|f\|_{\rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})}:=\|\rho f\|_{L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})}$.

Let $\rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$ be the space of functions $f: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ such that $\rho^{-1} f \in L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$, with the norm $\|f\|_{\rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})}:=\left\|\rho^{-1} f\right\|_{L_{1}(\mathbf{R})}$.

Definition 2.1. For a Borel measurable set $D \subset \mathbf{R}$ with non-empty interior, let $x \in \rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$ be such that $\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x(t) y(t) d t=0$ for any $y \in \rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$ such that $\left.Y\right|_{\mathbf{R} \backslash D} \equiv 0$, where $Y$ is the Fourier transform of $y$. In this case, we say that $D$ is a spectral gap of $x \in \rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$.

For $\Omega \in(0,+\infty)$, we denote by $\mathcal{V}(\rho, \Omega)$ the set of all signals $x \in \rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$ with the spectral gap $\mathbf{R} \backslash(-\Omega, \Omega)$. We call these signals band-limited.

It was shown in [12] that signals from $\mathcal{V}(\rho, \Omega)$ are continuous for any $\alpha \geq 0$.
We use the terms "spectral gap" and "band-limited" because, for a signal $x \in \rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$, Definition 2.1 means that $X(\omega)=0$ for $\omega \in D$, where $X$ the Fourier transform of $x$. The standard Fourier transform is not applicable for general type non-vanishing signals from $\rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$, however, we will use the terms "spectral gap" and "band-limited" for them as well. It is shown in Section 3 below that this is still justified with respect to the spectral properties of these signal.

We consider below spectral representation and some applications for unbounded signals from $\rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$.

Proposition 2.2. For any $\alpha \geq 0$ and $\Omega \in(0, \pi)$, there exists a sequence of functions $\left\{a_{k}(\cdot)\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \subset$ $\rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$ such that $\sup _{t \in \mathbf{R}} \sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}(1+|k|)^{\alpha}\left|a_{k}(t)\right|<+\infty$ and (1) holds, i.e., $x(t)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t) x(k)$ for any $t \in \mathbf{R}$. The corresponding series is absolutely convergent for each $t$.

In particular, it follows that, for any $t$, the coefficients $\left|a_{k}(t)\right|$ are decreasing as $\sim 1 / k^{\nu}$ for some $\nu>1+\alpha$.

Lemma 4.2 and Lemma 4.3 below provide a way to calculate $a_{k}(t)$ for any $\alpha \in[0,+\infty)$
For the case where $\alpha \in[0,1 / 2)$, it was possible to calculate these functions explicitly, as is Theorem 2.3 below.

Let $\Omega \in(0, \pi)$ be given. Let some even integer number $N$ be selected such that

$$
N>\frac{\Omega}{\pi-\Omega}
$$

It can be noted that we need to select larger $N$ for larger $\Omega$, i.e., $N \rightarrow+\infty$ as $\Omega \rightarrow \pi-0$.
For $t \in[N, N+1)$ and $\tau=t-N \in[0,1)$, let us select

$$
g(t)=\frac{\pi\lfloor t\rfloor}{t}=\frac{\pi N}{N+\tau}
$$

Here $\lfloor t \cdot=\min \{m \in \mathbb{Z}: t \geq m\}$.
It is easy to see that, for any $t \in[N, N+1)$, we have $g(t) \geq \pi N(N+1)^{-1}>\Omega$ and $g(t) t=\pi N$.
Assume that the function $g(t)$ is extended periodically from $[N, N+1)$ to $\mathbf{R}$. This function is right-continuous. In addition, $g(m)=\pi$ and $(t-m) g(t)=\pi N$ for any integer $m$ and any $t \in[N+m, N+m+1)$.

Theorem 2.3. If $\alpha \in[0,1 / 2)$ in (4), then, for band-limited signal $x \in \mathcal{V}(\rho, \Omega)$, for any $t \in \mathbf{R}$ and $m=\lfloor t-N\rfloor$, i.e., $t \in[N+m, N+m+1)$, we have that (1) holds, i.e., $x(t)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t) x(k)$ for $t \in \mathbf{R}$, where $a_{m}(t)=1-\frac{g(t)}{\pi}$, and

$$
a_{k}(t)=\frac{(t-m) \sin [g(t)(k-m)]}{\pi(k-m)(k-t)}, \quad k \neq m
$$

The corresponding series is absolutely convergent for each $t$ and is absolutely convergent uniformly on any bounded interval of $\mathbf{R}$.

In particular, formula (5) implies that $a_{k}(k)=1$, and that $a_{k}(l)=0$ for any integers $k$ and $l$ such that $k \neq l$.

It can be noted that, under the assumptions of Theorem 2.3, we have that

$$
a_{k}(t)=\frac{(t-m) g(t) \operatorname{sinc}[g(t)(k-m)]}{\pi(k-t)}=\frac{N \operatorname{sinc}[g(t)(k-m)]}{k-t}, \quad k \neq m
$$

We used here that $(t-m) g(t)=\pi N$.
Theorem 2.4. If $\alpha \in[0,3 / 2)$ in (4), then, for any band-limited signal $x \in \mathcal{V}(\rho, \Omega)$, for any $t \in \mathbf{R}$ and $m=\lfloor t-N\rfloor$, we have that (1) holds with

$$
a_{k}(t)=\frac{\sin [g(t)(k-m)]}{\pi(k-m-t)}+\frac{1}{\pi} \int_{g(t)}^{\pi}[P(t, \omega) \cos (-k+m)-Q(t, \omega) \sin (-k+m)] d \omega
$$

were

$$
P(t, \omega):=p_{3}(t) \omega^{3}+p_{2}(t) \omega^{2}+p_{1}(t) \omega+p_{0}, \quad Q(t, \omega):=q_{2}(t) \omega^{2}+q_{1}(t) \omega+q_{0}
$$

and where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{3}(t)=1 / 3, \quad p_{2}(t)=-\frac{1}{2}(g(t)+\pi), \quad p_{1}(t)=\pi g(t) \\
& p_{0}(t)=-\frac{1}{3} g(t)^{3}+\frac{1}{2}(g(t)+\pi) g(t)^{2}-\pi g(t)^{2}+1
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& q_{0}(t)=\frac{\pi-\gamma(t)}{\gamma(t)^{2}-\pi^{2}-2 g(t)^{2}+2 g(t) \pi} \\
& q_{1}(t)=1-2 q_{0}(t) g(t), \quad q_{2}(t)=-q_{0}(t) \pi^{2}-p_{1}(t) \pi
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding series is absolutely convergent for each $t \in \mathbf{R}$.

# 3 Background for the proofs 

In this section, we outline some results being used in the proof for the main Theorem 2.3.

## Some notations and definitions for spaces of functions

We denote by $\bar{z}$ the complex conjugation. We denote by $*$ the convolution

$$
(h * x)(t):=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} h(t-s) x(s) d s, \quad t \in \mathbf{R}
$$

For a Banach space $\mathcal{X}$, we denote by $\mathcal{X}^{*}$ its dual.
For $r \in[1, \infty)$, we denote by $\ell_{r}$ the set of all processes (signals) $x: \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$, such that $\|x\|_{\ell_{r}}:=\left(\sum_{t=-\infty}^{\infty}|x(t)|^{r}\right)^{1 / r}<+\infty$. We denote by $\ell_{\infty}$ the set of all processes (signals) $x: \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$, such that $\|x\|_{\ell_{\infty}}:=\sup _{t \in \mathbb{Z}}|x(t)|<+\infty$.

For $k=1,2, \ldots$, we denote by $W_{r}^{d}(-\pi, \pi)$ the Sobolev space of functions $f:[-\pi, \pi] \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ that belong to $L_{2}(-\pi, \pi)$ together with the distributional derivatives up to the $k$ th order, and such that $d f^{t}(-\pi) / d \omega=d f^{k}(\pi) / d \omega^{k}$ for $k=0,1,2,3, \ldots, d-1$.

Let $\mathcal{B}(\rho)$ be the space of continuous functions $f \in C(\mathbf{R})$ with the finite norm $\|f\|_{\mathcal{B}(\rho)}:=$ $\|\widehat{f}(\omega)\|_{\rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})}$, where $\widehat{f}(\omega)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-i \omega s} f(s) d s$ is the Fourier transform of $f$. By the choice of this norm, this is a separable Banach space that is isomorphic to $\rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$, and the embedding $C(\mathbf{R}) \subset \mathcal{B}(\rho)$ is continuous.

In particular, the definition for $\mathcal{B}(\rho)$ implies that $Y \in \mathcal{B}(\rho)$ in Definition 2.1.
Let $\rho \ell_{1}$ be the space of sequences $x: \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ such that $\|x\|_{\rho \ell_{1}}:=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \rho(k)^{-1}|x(k)|<+\infty$.
Let $\rho^{-1} \ell_{\infty}$ be the space of sequences $x: \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ such that $\|x\|_{\rho^{-1} \ell_{\infty}}:=\sup _{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \rho(k)|x(k)|<$ $+\infty$.

Let $\mathcal{C}(\rho)$ be the space of functions $f \in C([-\pi, \pi])$ with the finite norm $\|f\|_{\mathcal{C}(\rho)}=\|\widehat{f}\|_{\rho \ell_{1}}:=$ $\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \rho(k)^{-1}\left|\widehat{f}_{k}\right|$, where $\widehat{f}_{k}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} e^{-i k s} f(s) d s$ are the Fourier coefficients of $f$. This is a separable Banach space that is isomorphic to $\rho \ell_{1}$. In particular, if $\rho \equiv 1$, then functions from $\mathcal{C}(\rho)$ have absolutely convergent Fourier series on $[-\pi, \pi]$.

Lemma 3.1. Let integer $d>\alpha+1 / 2$ and $r \in(1,2]$ be such that $r>(d-\alpha)^{-1}$. Then the following holds.
(i) the embedding $W_{r}^{d}(\mathbf{R}) \subset \mathcal{B}(\rho)$ is continuous, and
(ii) the embedding $W_{r}^{d}(-\pi, \pi) \subset \mathcal{C}(\rho)$ is continuous.

It can be noted that, since $d-\alpha>1 / 2$ and hence $(d-\alpha)^{-1}<2$, required $r$ exist.
Lemma 3.2. Let $r$ be such as in Lemma 3.1. Let $h \in W_{r}^{1}(\mathbf{R})$ be such that $h(-\pi)=$ $h(\pi)$, let $H$ be its Fourier transform, and let $m \in \mathbb{Z}$. Then $\left.H(t, \cdot) e^{i \cdot m}\right|_{[-\pi, \pi]} \in \mathcal{C}(\rho)$, and $\rho(m)\left\|H(t, \cdot) e^{i \cdot m}\right|_{[-\pi, \pi]}\left\|_{\mathcal{C}(\rho)} \leq\right\| h_{[-\pi, \pi]}\left\|_{W_{r}^{1}(-\pi, \pi) \text { for any } t .}\right.$
Lemma 3.3. Let $h \in \rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$, and let $H$ be its Fourier transform. Then $H e^{i \cdot t}=\left(h * e^{i \omega}\right)(t)$, $H e^{i \cdot t} \in \mathcal{B}(\rho)$, and $\rho(t)\left\|H e^{i \cdot t}\right\|_{\mathcal{B}(\rho)} \leq\|h\|_{\rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})}$ for any $t \in \mathbf{R}$. In addition, the function $H e^{i \cdot t}$ is continuous in the topology of $\mathcal{B}(\rho)$ with respect to $t \in \mathbf{R}$.

Spectral representation for signals from $\rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$
We assume that each $X \in L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$ represents an element of the dual space $C(\mathbf{R})^{*}$ such that $\langle X, f\rangle=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} X(\omega) f(\omega) d \omega$ for $f \in C(\mathbf{R})$. We will use the same notation $\langle\cdot, \cdot\rangle$ for the extension of this bilinear form on $\mathcal{B}(\rho)^{*} \times \mathcal{B}(\rho)$.

We will use the space $\mathcal{B}(\rho)$ and its dual $\mathcal{B}(\rho)^{*}$ to define formally a spectral representation for $x \in \rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$ via $X \in \mathcal{B}(\rho)^{*}$ such that

$$
\langle X, \bar{f}\rangle=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x(t) \bar{\varphi}(t) d t
$$

for any $f \in \mathcal{B}(\rho)$, where $\varphi \in \rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$ is the Fourier transform for $f$. We use notation $X=\mathcal{F} x$ for the corresponding operator $\mathcal{F}: \rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R}) \rightarrow \mathcal{B}(\rho)^{*}$.

For the case where $\rho \equiv 1$, this definition was used in Chapter VI in [18]. In Chapter III in [17], a similar definition was used for the Fourier transforms for pseudo-measures on $[-\pi, \pi]$ represented as elements of $\ell_{\infty}$; see also $[11,12,24]$.

It can be noted that, for any $x \in \rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$, the corresponding $X=\mathcal{F} x$ is the weak* limit in $\mathcal{B}(\rho)^{*}$ as $t \rightarrow+\infty$ of the sequence of functions $X_{m}(\omega):=\int_{-m}^{m} e^{-i \omega t} x(t) d t$ defined on $\mathbf{R}$ (see [12]).

Proposition 3.4. Let $h \in \rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$. For any $x \in \rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$ and $X=\mathcal{F} x, H=\mathcal{F} h$, we have that

$$
(h * x)(t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\langle X, H(\cdot) e^{i \cdot t}\rangle \quad \text { for } \quad t \in \mathbf{R}
$$

It can noted that, for $x \in L_{1}(\mathbf{R}), \mathcal{F} x$ is the standard Fourier transform. In this case, $X \in$ $C(\mathbf{R})$. Since $H e^{i \cdot t} \in \rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R}) \subset L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$, the right hand part of (8) is defined by standard way as $\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} X(\omega) H(\omega) e^{i \omega t} d \omega$.

Spectral representation for band-limited signals from $\rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$
The following lemma connects Definition 2.1 with the spectral representation.
Lemma 3.5. A signal $x \in \rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$ has a spectral gap $D \subset \mathbf{R}$ if and only if $\langle\mathcal{F} x, f\rangle=0$ for any $f \in \mathcal{B}(\rho)$ such that $\left.f\right|_{\mathbf{R} \backslash D} \equiv 0$. In this case, for any $f_{1}, f_{2} \in \mathcal{B}(\rho)$, if $f_{1}(\omega)=f_{2}(\omega)$ for all $\omega \in[-\Omega, \Omega]$ then $\left\langle\mathcal{F} x, f_{1}\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathcal{F} x, f_{2}\right\rangle$.

Proposition 3.6. Suppose that $\Omega_{1}>\Omega$ and a function $E: \mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ be such that the following holds:

(i) $E(t, \omega)=e^{i \omega t}$ for all $t \in \mathbf{R}$ and $\omega \in\left[-\Omega_{1}, \Omega_{1}\right]$.
(ii) For any $t, E(t, \cdot) \in \mathcal{B}(\rho)$ and $\sup _{t \in \mathbf{R}} \rho(t)\|E(t, \cdot)\|_{\mathcal{B}(\rho)}<+\infty$.

Then, for any $x \in \mathcal{V}(\rho, \Omega)$ and $X=\mathcal{F} x$, we have that

$$
x(t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\langle X, E(t, \cdot)\rangle \quad \text { for } \quad t \in \mathbf{R}
$$

# 4 Proofs
## Proof of background results

Proof of Lemma 3.1. The proof for Lemma 3.1(i) can be found in [12]. Let us prove statement (ii). Let $f \in \stackrel{p}{W}_{r}^{d}(-\pi, \pi)$, and let $\widehat{f}_{k}$ be its Fourier coefficients. By the Hausdorff-Young inequality, we have for $r \in(1,2]$ that

$$
\left(\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}(1+|k|)^{d q}\left|\widehat{f}_{k}\right|^{q}\right)^{1 / q} \leq C_{r}\|f\|_{\stackrel{p}{W}_{r}^{d}(-\pi, \pi)}
$$

for $q:=(1-1 / r)^{-1}$ and some $C_{r}>0$ that is independent on $f$. Further, we have that $d^{l} f(\omega) / d \omega^{l} \in$ $L_{r}(-\pi, \pi)$ for $l=0,1, \ldots, d$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \rho(k)^{-1}\left|\widehat{f}_{k}\right| & =\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}(1+|k|)^{\alpha}\left|\widehat{f}_{k}\right|=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}(1+|k|)^{\alpha-d}(1+|k|)^{d}\left|\widehat{f}_{k}\right| \\
& \leq\left(\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}(1+|k|)^{(\alpha-d) r}\right)^{1 / r}\left(\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}(1+|k|)^{d q}\left|\widehat{f}_{k}\right|^{q}\right)^{1 / q} \leq C_{d, r}\|f\|_{\stackrel{p}{W}_{r}^{d}(-\pi, \pi)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
C_{d, r}:=C_{r}\left(\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \frac{(1+|k|)^{\alpha r}}{(1+|k|)^{d r}}\right)^{1 / r}<+\infty
$$

We used here, that, since $d>\alpha+1 / 2$, we have that $d-\alpha>1 / 2$ and $1 /(d-\alpha)<2$.
By the choice of $r$, we have that $r>1 /(d-\alpha)$ and $r(d-\alpha)=d r-\alpha r>1$.
This proves statement (ii). This completes the proof of Lemma 3.1.
Proof of Lemma 3.2. Let $\widehat{h}(k)$ be the Fourier coefficients of $h_{[-\pi, \pi]}$. For $m \in \mathbb{Z}$, we have that $H(\omega) e^{i \omega m}=e^{i \omega m} \sum_{\nu \in \mathbb{Z}} \widehat{h}(k) e^{-i \omega \nu}=\sum_{\nu \in \mathbb{Z}} \widehat{h}(\nu) e^{-i \omega(\nu-m)}=\sum_{\nu \in \mathbb{Z}} \widehat{h}(\nu) e^{i \omega(m-\nu)}=\sum_{\nu \in \mathbb{Z}} \widehat{h}(m+\nu) e^{-i \omega \nu}$

for $\omega \in \mathbf{R}$. Hence, for any $t \in \mathbf{R}$ and $C_{r, q}$ from the proof of Lemma 3.1,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|H e^{i \omega m}\right\|_{\mathcal{C}(\rho)}=\sum_{\nu \in \mathbb{Z}} \rho(\nu)^{-1}|\widehat{h}(\nu+m)|=\sum_{\nu \in \mathbb{Z}} \rho(\nu-m)^{-1}|\widehat{h}(\nu)| \leq \rho(m)^{-1} \sum_{\nu \in \mathbb{Z}} \rho(\nu)^{-1}|\widehat{h}(\nu)| \\
& =\rho(m)^{-1}\|\widehat{h}\|_{\rho \ell_{1}} \leq C_{r, q} \rho(m)^{-1}\|h\|_{\left.\right|_{W_{r}^{1}(-\pi, \pi)}^{\infty}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We used here that $\rho(m) \rho(\nu) \leq \rho(\nu-m)$. This completes the proof of Lemma 3.2.
The proof of Lemma 3.3 can be found in [12].
Proof of Proposition 3.4. Let $g(s):=\bar{h}(t-s)$, i.e., $\bar{h}(s)=g(t-s), s \in \mathbf{R}$. Let $G=\mathcal{F} g$. By the definitions,

$$
(h * x)(t)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x(s) h(t-s) d s=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x(s) \bar{g}(s) d s=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\langle X, \bar{G}\rangle \quad \text { for } \quad t \in \mathbf{R}
$$

We have that $G(\omega)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-i \omega s} g(t) d s$ and

$$
\bar{G}(\omega)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{i \omega s} \bar{g}(s) d s=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{i \omega s} h(t-s) d t=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{i \omega(t-\nu)} h(\nu) d \nu=e^{i \omega t} H(\omega)
$$

The proof of Lemma 3.5 follows immediately from the definitions.
Proof of Proposition 3.6. Let $\mathcal{H}\left(O_{1}\right)$ be the set of all $h \in \mathcal{B}(\rho)$ such that $h(t)=0$ if $|t|>\Omega_{1}-\Omega$. Let $y \in \mathbf{C}$ be defined as

$$
y(t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\langle X, E(t, \cdot)\rangle
$$

By Proposition 3.4 and by the choice of $E$ and $X$, we have that

$$
(h * y)(t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\langle X, H E(t, \cdot)\rangle
$$

for all $t$ and all $h \in \mathcal{H}\left(O_{1}\right), H=\mathcal{F} h$.
By Proposition 3.4 and Lemma 3.5, we have that

$$
(h * x)(t)=(h * y)(t)
$$

for all $t$ and all $h \in \mathcal{H}\left(O_{1}\right)$. Hence $x=y$. This completes the proof of Proposition 3.6.

# 4.1 Proof of Proposition 2.2 

Lemma 4.1. Suppose that there exists a function $E: \mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ satisfying the conditions of Proposition 3.6 with $\Omega_{1} \in(\Omega, \pi)$ such that, for any $t, E(t, \cdot) \|_{[-\pi, \pi]} \in \mathcal{C}(\rho)$ and $\sup _{t \in \mathbf{R}} \rho(t)\|E(t, \cdot)\|_{[-\pi, \pi]} \|_{\mathcal{C}(\rho)}<+\infty$. Let

$$
a_{k}(t):=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} E(t, \omega) e^{-i \omega k} d \omega
$$

Then $\left\{a_{k}(t)\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \in \rho \ell_{1}$ for all $t \in \mathbf{R}, \sup _{t \in \mathbf{R}} \rho(t)\left\|\left\{a_{k}(t)\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}\right\|_{\rho \ell_{1}}<+\infty$, and any signal $x \in$ $\mathcal{V}(\rho, \Omega)$ can be represented as (1) for $t \in[N, N+1)$, where the corresponding series is absolutely convergent for each $t$ as well as in $\rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$.

In addition, if $E(t, \omega)=\overline{E(t,-\omega)}$ for all $t$ and $\omega$, then $a_{k}(t) \in \mathbf{R}$.
Proof of Lemma 4.1. Suppose that $E(t, \omega)$ and $\left\{a_{k}(t)\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}$ are such as described.
By the assumptions, $e^{i \omega t}=E(t, \omega)$ for $\omega \in\left[-\Omega_{1}, \Omega_{1}\right]$. By Proposition 4.1, it follows that

$$
x(t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\langle X, E(\cdot, t)\rangle
$$

In particular,

$$
x(k)=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\langle X, E(k, \cdot)\rangle, \quad k \in \mathbb{Z}
$$

By the choice of $a_{k}$, and by the properties of Fourier series, we have that

$$
E(t, \omega)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t) e^{i \omega k}, \quad t \in \mathbf{R}, \quad \omega \in[-\pi, \pi]
$$

where the series are absolutely convergent for any $t, \omega$. The condition that $\left.E(t, \cdot)\right|_{[-\pi, \pi]} \in \mathcal{C}(\rho)$ implies that $\left\{a_{k}(t)\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \in \rho \ell_{1}$ and that the sum

$$
E(t, \cdot)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t) E(k, \cdot)
$$

converges in $\mathcal{B}(\rho)$ for any $t$. The condition that $\sup _{t \in \mathbf{R}} \rho(t)\left\|E(t, \cdot)\right\|_{[-\pi, \pi]}\left\|_{\mathcal{C}(\rho)}<+\infty\right.$ implies that $\sup _{t \in \mathbf{R}} \rho(t)\left\|\left\{a_{k}(t)\right\}_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}\right\|_{\rho \ell_{1}}<+\infty$.

We have that

$$
e^{i \omega t}=E(t, \omega)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t) e^{i \omega k}=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t) E(k, \omega), \quad t \in \mathbf{R}, \quad \omega \in\left[-\Omega_{1}, \Omega_{1}\right]
$$

where the series are absolutely convergent for any $t, \omega$.

By (10), it follows that

$$
x(t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left\langle X, \sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t) E(k, \omega)\right\rangle=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t) \frac{1}{2 \pi}\langle X, E(k, \omega)\rangle=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t) x(k)
$$

This completes the proof of Lemma 4.1.
Let some $\Omega_{1} \in(\Omega, \pi)$ be selected such that

$$
g(t) \geq \Omega_{1}
$$

Clearly, such $\Omega_{1}$ exists.
Lemma 4.2. Let $r$ and $d$, be such as defined in Lemma 3.1, given $\alpha>0$. Let a function $E_{N}:[N, N+1) \times \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ be defined such that $E_{N}(t, \cdot) \in W_{r}^{d}(\mathbf{R})$ for any $t \in[N, N+1)$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E_{N}(t, \omega)=e^{i \omega t}, \quad \omega \in[-g(t), g(t)] \\
& \sup _{t \in[N, N+1)}\left\|E_{N}(t, \cdot)\right|_{W_{r}^{d}(\mathbf{R})}<+\infty \\
& \frac{d^{l}}{d \omega^{l}} E_{N}(t, \pi)=\frac{d^{l}}{d \omega^{l}} E_{N}(t,-\pi), \quad t \in \mathbf{R}, \quad l=0,1, \ldots, d-1
\end{aligned}
$$

Further, let the function $E: \mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{C}$ be defined as

$$
E(t, \omega)=E_{N}(t-m, \omega) e^{i \omega m}, \quad \omega \in \mathbf{R}, \quad t \in[N+m, N+m+1), \quad m \in \mathbb{Z}
$$

Then the conditions of Proposition 4.1 hold for these $E$.
Clearly, if $E_{N}(t, \omega)=\overline{E_{N}(t,-\omega)}$ for all $t$ and $\omega$, then $E(t, \omega)=\overline{E(t,-\omega)}$ for all $t$ and $\omega$.
Proof of Lemma 4.2. It is easy to see that, by (12), condition (i) of Proposition 3.6 is satisfied for selected $E$. We have that $E_{N}(t, \cdot) \in \mathcal{B}(\rho) \subset W_{r}^{1}(\mathbf{R})$ for any $t \in[N, N+1)$. By (13), we have that

$$
\sup _{t \in[N, N+1)}\left\|E_{N}(t, \cdot)\right\|_{[-\pi, \pi]}\left\|_{\mathcal{B}(\rho)} \leq \text { const } \cdot \sup _{t \in[N, N+1)}\right\| E_{N}(t, \cdot) \|_{W_{r}^{1}(\mathbf{R})}<+\infty
$$

By Lemma 3.3(iii), we have for $u \in \mathcal{B}(\rho)$ that

$$
e^{i \cdot m} u \in \mathcal{B}(\rho), \quad\|u\|_{\mathcal{B}(\rho)} \leq \rho(m)^{-1}\left\|e^{i \cdot m} u\right\|_{\mathcal{B}(\rho)}
$$

By (14), we have that $\left.E_{N}(t, \cdot)\right|_{[-\pi, \pi]} \in \stackrel{p}{W}_{r}^{1}(-\pi, \pi) \subset \mathcal{C}(\rho)$ for any $t \in[N, N+1)$, and

$$
\sup _{t \in[N, N+1)}\left\|E_{N}(t, \cdot)\right\|_{[-\pi, \pi]}\left\|_{\mathcal{C}(\rho)} \leq \text { const } \cdot \sup _{t \in[N, N+1)}\right\| E_{N}(t, \cdot) \|_{[-\pi, \pi]}\left\|_{\stackrel{p}{W}_{r}^{1}(-\pi, \pi)}<+\infty\right.
$$

By Lemma 3.2(iii), for any $v \in \mathcal{C}(\rho)$, we have that

$$
e^{i \cdot m} v \in \mathcal{C}(\rho), \quad\left\|e^{i \cdot m} v\right\|_{\mathcal{C}(\rho)} \leq \rho(m)^{-1}\|v\|_{\mathcal{C}(\rho)}
$$

Hence conditions of Proposition 3.6 is satisfied for $E(t, \omega)$. It follows $E(t, \omega)=\overline{E(t,-\omega)}$ for all $t$ and $\omega$. This completes the proof of Proposition 4.2.

Lemma 4.3. Let $d \in \mathbb{Z}$ be such that $d>\alpha+1 / 2$. Let $r \in(1 /(d-a), 2]$. A possible choice of $\left.E_{N}(\cdot, t)\right|_{\{\omega:|\omega| \in|g(t), \pi]\}}$ satisfying conditions of Lemma 4.2 is the following. If $d$ is even, then $E_{N}(t, \omega)=P(t, \omega)+i Q(t, \omega)$, where $P(t, \omega):[N, N+1) \times \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ and $P(t, \omega):[N, N+1) \times \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ are polynomials with respect to $\omega$ and such that all the following conditions hold.

1. $P(t, \cdot)$ is even, $Q(t, \cdot)$ is odd, $P(t, g(t))=1, Q(t, g(t))=0, Q(t, \pi)=0$. If $d \geq 2$, then $P_{\omega}^{\prime}(t, \pi)=0, Q_{\omega}^{\prime}(t, g(t))=t, Q_{\omega}^{\prime}(t, \pi)=0$.
2. If $d \geq 3$, then $P_{\omega \omega}^{\prime \prime}(t, g(t))=-t^{2}, Q_{\omega \omega}^{\prime \prime}(t, g(t))=0, Q_{\omega \omega}^{\prime \prime}(t, \pi)=0$.
3. If $d \geq 2 l$ for an integer $l \geq 2$ then

$$
\left.\frac{\partial^{2 l-1} P}{\partial \omega^{2 l-1}}(t, \omega)\right|_{\omega=g(t)}=0,\left.\quad \frac{\partial^{2 l-1} Q}{\partial \omega^{2 l-1}}(t, \omega)\right|_{\omega=g(t)}=(-1)^{l-1} t^{2 l-1}
$$

4. If $d \geq 2 l+1$ for an integer $l \geq 2$ then

$$
\left.\frac{\partial^{2 l} P}{\partial \omega^{2 l}}(t, \omega)\right|_{\omega=g(t)}=(-1)^{l-1} t^{2 l-1},\left.\quad \frac{\partial^{2 l} Q}{\partial \omega^{2 l}}(t, \omega)\right|_{\omega=g(t)}=0
$$

The corresponding coefficients $a_{k}(t)$ are real.
It can be noted that the choice of function $\xi$ does not affect the values $a_{k}(t)$.
Proof of Lemma 4.3. Clearly, we have that

$$
\left.\frac{\partial^{k} e^{i t \omega}}{\partial \omega^{k}}\right|_{\omega= \pm g(t)}=(i t)^{k} e^{ \pm i t g(t)}=(i t)^{k}, \quad k=1,2, \ldots
$$

since $t g(t)=\pi N$ and $N$ is even integer, i.e. $e^{ \pm i g(t) t}=1$. It can be verified directly that the choice of $E_{N}$ ensures that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.E_{N}(t, \omega)\right|_{\omega= \pm g(t)}=\left.e^{i t \omega}\right|_{\omega= \pm g(t)}, \quad E_{N}(t, \pi)=E_{N}(t,-\pi), \\
& \left.\frac{\partial^{k} E_{N} t, \omega)}{\partial \omega^{k}}\right|_{\omega= \pm g(t)}=\left.\frac{\partial^{k} e^{i t \omega}}{\partial \omega^{k}}\right|_{\omega= \pm g(t)}, \quad \frac{\partial^{k} E_{N}(t, \omega)}{\partial \omega^{k}}\right|_{\omega=-\pi}=\left.\frac{\partial^{k} e^{i t \mu(t, \omega)}}{\partial \omega^{k}}\right|_{\omega=\pi}
\end{aligned}
$$

This ensures that $E_{N}$ satisfying conditions of Lemma 4.2. This completes the proof of Lemma 4.3.

Lemma 4.4. Let $E$ and $\left\{a_{k}\right\}$ be selected as in Lemma 4.1 and Lemma 4.2. For any $k, m \in \mathbb{Z}$, we have that

$$
a_{k}(t+m)=a_{k-m}(t)
$$

Proof of Lemma 4.4. Let $N$ be defined as in Lemma 4.2, and let $t=N+\tau$, By the definitions, $E(t, \omega)=e^{i M \omega} E(\tau, t)$, where $M \in \mathbb{Z}$ is such that $\tau=t-M \in[N, N+1)$. Hence $E(t+m, \omega)=$ $e^{i m \omega} E(t, \omega)$ and

$$
a_{k}(t+m)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} e^{i m \omega} E(t, \omega) e^{-i \omega k} d \omega=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} E(t, \omega) e^{-i \omega(k-m)} d \omega=a_{k-m}(t)
$$

This completes the proof of Lemma 4.4.
Corollary 4.5. Let $t, E$ and $\left\{a_{k}\right\}$ be such as selected as in Proposition 4.1 and Lemma 4.2. Then for any $m \in \mathbb{Z}$, any signal $x \in \mathcal{V}(\rho, \Omega)$ can be represented, for $t \in[N+m, N+m+1)$, as

$$
x(t)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k-m}(t-m) x(k)
$$

The corresponding series is absolutely convergent for each $t$.
Proof of Corollary 4.5. Let $\widetilde{x}(t):=x(t+m)$. It is easy to see that $\widetilde{x} \in \mathcal{V}(\rho, \Omega)$. Clearly, $x(t)=\widetilde{x}(t-m)$ for all $t$. By Proposition 4.7, we have that

$$
\widetilde{x}(s)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(s) \widetilde{x}(k), \quad s \in[0,1)
$$

Hence, for $t \in[m+N, m+N+1)$,

$$
x(t)=\widetilde{x}(t-m)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t-m) \widetilde{x}(k)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{k}(t-m) x(k+m)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} a_{d-m}(t-m) x(d)
$$

This completes the proof of Corollary 4.5.
Remark 4.6. Corollary 4.5 is due to the particular choice of acceptable $E$. Possibly, there exist choices of $E$ such that conditions required for Lemma 4.1 are satisfied but Corollary 4.5 does not hold.

Proof of Proposition 2.2 follows from Lemma 4.1 and Corollary 4.5.

# 4.2 Proof of Theorem 2.3 

Lemma 4.7. Assume that $\alpha \in[0,1 / 2)$ and that $E$ is selected as in Lemma 4.2 with $d=1$, $P(t, \omega) \equiv g(t), Q(, \omega) \equiv 0$ in Lemma 4.3. Let $a_{k}(t)$ be the corresponding coefficients defined as in Proposition 4.1. Then, for $t \in[N, N+1)$, we have that $a_{0}(t)=1-\frac{g(t)}{\pi}$ and

$$
a_{k}(t)=\frac{t \sin [g(t) k]}{\pi k(k-t)}, \quad k \neq 0
$$

It can be noted that, since $g(t) t=\pi N$ for $t \in[N, N+1)$, we have that

$$
a_{k}(t)=\frac{g(t) t \operatorname{sinc}(g(t) k)}{\pi(k-t)}=\frac{N \operatorname{sinc}(g(t) k)}{k-t}, \quad k \neq 0
$$

Proof of Lemma 4.7. Given that $\alpha \in[0,1 / 2)$, we can select $d=1$. Clearly, $a_{k}(N)=0$ for $k \neq N$, and $a_{N}(N)=1$, by the choice of $g(k)=\pi$ for $k \in \mathbb{Z}$.

By the choice of $E_{N}$, we have that

$$
a_{k}(t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} e^{-i \omega k} E_{N}(t, \omega) d \omega=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left(\alpha_{k}(t)+\beta_{k}(t)\right)
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \alpha_{k}(t)=\int_{-g(t)}^{g(t)} e^{-i \omega k} e^{i \omega t} d \omega \\
& \beta_{k}(t)=\int_{-\pi}^{-g(t)} e^{-i \omega k} e^{i g(t) t} d \omega+\int_{g(t)}^{\pi} e^{-i \omega k} e^{i g(t) t} d \omega=\int_{-\pi}^{-g(t)} e^{-i \omega k} d \omega+\int_{g(t)}^{\pi} e^{-i \omega k} d \omega
\end{aligned}
$$

We used here again that $g(t) t=\pi N$.
Consider the case where $k \neq 0$. In this case,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\alpha_{k}(t)=\int_{-g(t)}^{g(t)} e^{-i \omega k} e^{i \omega t} d \omega=\frac{e^{i g(t)(t-k)}-e^{-i g(t)(t-k)}}{i(t-k)}=\frac{e^{-i g(t) k}-e^{i g(t) k}}{i(t-k)}=-\frac{2 \sin (g(t) k)}{t-k} \\
\beta_{k}(t)=\frac{e^{i g(t) k}-e^{i \pi k}}{-i k}+\frac{e^{-i \pi k}-e^{-i g(t) k}}{-i k}=\frac{e^{-i g(t) k}-e^{i g(t) k}}{i k}=-\frac{2 \sin (g(t) k)}{k}
\end{gathered}
$$

and

$$
a_{k}(t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left(\alpha_{k}(t)+\beta_{k}(t)\right)=-\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left(\frac{2 \sin (g(t) k)}{t-k}+e^{i g(t) t} \frac{2 \sin (g(t) k)}{k}\right)
$$

Hence

$$
a_{k}(t)=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left(\alpha_{k}(t)+\beta_{k}(t)\right)=-\frac{1}{\pi} \sin (g(t) k)\left(\frac{1}{t-k}+\frac{1}{k}\right)=\frac{1}{\pi} \sin (g(t) k) \frac{t}{k(k-t)}
$$

For the case where $k=0$, we have

$$
\alpha_{0}(t)=\int_{-g(t)}^{g(t)} e^{i \omega t} d \omega=-\frac{e^{i g(t) t}-e^{-i g(t) t}}{i t}=-\frac{e^{i N \pi}-e^{-i N \pi}}{i t}
$$

Since $t \geq N>0$, we have that $\alpha_{0}(t)=0$. Further, we have $\beta_{0}(t)=2 e^{i g(t) t}(\pi-g(t))=2(\pi-g(t))$. Hence $a_{0}(t)=1-\frac{g(t)}{\pi}$. This completes the proof of Lemma 4.7.

Proof of Theorem 2.3. The proof for the case where $t \notin[N, N+1)$ follows immediately from Lemma 4.7 and Corollary 4.5. Convergence for any $t$ follows immediately from Proposition 4.2, Lemma 4.7, and Corollary 4.5 since $g(t-m)=g(t)$ for all $m \in \mathbb{Z}$.

Let us prove uniform convergence on bounded intervals. It suffices to consider intervals $I=$ $[-T, T]$, where $T>0$ can be arbitrarily large.

For $t \in \mathbf{R}, k \in \mathbb{Z}, n \in \mathbb{Z}, n>2 T+1$, let $b_{k}(t):=a_{k}(t) x(k)$, let $A(t, n):=\{k \in \mathbb{Z}: t-n \leq$ $k \leq t+n\}$, and let $x_{n}(t):=\sum_{k \in A(t, n)} b_{k}(t)$. We have that

$$
x(t)=x_{n}(t)+\sum_{k \notin A(t, n)} b_{k}(t)
$$

For any $t \in \mathbf{R}$, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{t \in[-T, T]} \sum_{k \notin A(t, n)}\left|b_{k}(t)\right|=\sup _{t \in[-T, T]} \sum_{k \notin A(t, n)}\left|\rho(k)^{-1} a_{k}(t) \rho(k) x(k)\right| \\
& \leq \sup _{t \in[-T, T]}\left(\sum_{k \notin A(t, n)} \rho(k)^{-1}\left|a_{k}(t)\right|\right) \sup _{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \rho(k)|x(k)| \leq c_{n}(t)\|x\|_{\rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
c_{n}(t):=\sup _{t \in[-T, T]}\left(\sum_{k \notin A(t, n)} \rho(k)^{-1}\left|a_{k}(t)\right|\right)
$$

We have that $|k-t|>|k|-2 T>0$ for $k \notin A(t, n)$ and

$$
\left|a_{k}(t)\right| \leq \frac{N}{|k-m||k-t|}, \quad k \neq m, \quad a_{m}(t)=1-\frac{g(t)}{\pi} \in(0,1)
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
& c_{n}(t) \leq \sup _{t \in[-T, T]}\left(\sum_{k \notin A(t, n), k \neq m} \rho(k)^{-1} \frac{N}{|k-m||k-t|}+\rho(m)^{-1} a_{m}(t)\right) \\
& =N \sup _{t \in[-T, T]}\left(\sum_{k \notin A(t, n), k \neq m} \frac{(|1+| k|)^{\alpha}}{|k-m||k-t|}+\rho(m)^{-1} a_{m}(t)\right) \\
& \leq N \sum_{k \notin A(t, n), k \neq m} \frac{(|1+| k|)^{\alpha}}{|k-m|||k|-2 T|}+\rho(m)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $\sup _{t \in[-T, T]}\|b .(t)\|_{\ell_{1}}<+\infty$ and $x_{n}(t) \rightarrow x(t)$ as $n \rightarrow+\infty$ uniformly in $t \in[-T, T]$. This completes the proof of Theorem 2.3.

Proof of Theorem 2.4. We can select $E_{N}$ as in Lemma 4.3 with $d=2$. It is easy to verify directly that the assumptions of Lemma 4.3 are satisfied with this choices. Then the interpolation formula and its absolute convergence for any $t$ follows from Proposition 4.2, Lemma 4.7, and Corollary 4.5. This completes the proof of Theorem 2.4.

Remark 4.8. The integrals in Theorem 2.4 can be calculated explicitly by parts as integrals of polynomials multiplied on $e^{-i \omega k}$., and $a_{k}$ can be presented explicitly. The resulting formulae will be tremendous, but could streamline calculations. In fact, or any positive $d \in \mathbb{Z}$, one can, similarly to Theorems 2.3-2.4, provide formulas for $a_{k}$.

# 5 Some numerical experiments 

In some straightforward numerical experiments, we applied truncated interpolation with

- the classical interpolation formula (2) covering decaying signals,
- our new formula (5) covering unbounded signals with a sublinear growth rate $\alpha<1 / 2$;
- the formula with the coefficients calculated as in Theorem 2.4 covering unbounded signals with the growth rate $\alpha<3 / 2$.

For these experiments, we used $\Omega=\frac{5 \pi}{6}$. The number $N$ was selected as the smallest even number such that $N>\Omega_{1} /\left(\pi-\Omega_{1}\right)$ with $\Omega_{1}=(\Omega+\pi) / 2$. It can be noted that these choices define the coefficients of selected interpolations formulae uniquely.

We experimented with band-limited signals from $L_{2}(\mathbf{R})$ and unbounded signals featuring linear growth.

## Experiments with band-limited decaying signals from $L_{2}(\mathbf{R})$

For band-limited signals from $L_{2}(\mathbf{R})$, we found that the results were indistinguishable for all three interpolation formulae.

First, let us show the results of our experiments using an example of a band-limited signal $x(t)=\operatorname{sinc}(\Omega(t-1)+1 / 2)-2 \operatorname{sinc}(\Omega(t+2) / \sqrt{2}-1)$.

This type of signals has been used for numerical examples in [19].
We estimated $x(t)$ at arbitrarily selected single points. We calculated the error of interpolation as $|x(t)-\widehat{x}(t)|$, where $x(t)$ is the true value, $\widehat{x}(t)$ is the value obtained by the corresponding truncated interpolation formulae with summation over $k \in\{-L+\lfloor t\rfloor,-L+\lfloor t\rfloor+1, \ldots, L+\lfloor t\rfloor\}$, for various integers $L>0$.

For $t=-1.71$ and $\Omega=5 \pi / 6$, we can select $N=6$ and $m=-8$. For this case, $x(t)=$ -1.8827743114725989937 . Following our approach, we select $N=N(\Omega)=6$; this means that we have to select $m=-8$. We obtained the following results.

- For $L=50$, the error for the classical formula (2) is the error for the classical formula (2) is $7.3444679278278357515 \times 10^{-6}$, the error for our formulae (1)-(5) in Theorem 2.3 is $3.0762119742622218155 \times 10^{-6}$, the error for our formulae in Theorem 2.4 is $2.3713406063219366615 \times 10^{-6}$.

For $L=100$, the error for the classical formula (2) is $5.25190050757462501 \times 10^{-5}$, the error for our formulae (1)-(5) in Theorem 2.3 is $2.4873476931475124729 \times 10^{-6}$, the error for for our formulae in Theorem 2.4 is 5.0347767932557019321 $\times 10^{-7}$.

- For $L=500$, the error for the classical formula (2) is $2.2207117567063505703 \times 10^{-7}$, the error for our formulae (1)-(5) in Theorem 2.3 is $4.3494727819393119717 \times 10^{-9}$, the error for for our formulae in Theorem 2.4 is $1.1088974183337541035 \times 10^{-10}$.

- For $L=50$, the error for the classical formula (2) is $\times 10^{-5}$, the error for our formulae (1)-(5) in Theorem 2.3 is 0.0045069457472912688445 , the error for our formulae in Theorem 2.4 is 0.0053064993469169596807 .

- For $L=100$, the error for the classical formula (2) is 1.1277366571020146502 , the error for our formulae (1)-(5) in Theorem 2.3 is 0.05162016886519327219 , the error for our interpolation calculated as Theorem 2.4 is 0.011368950797937649178 .
- For $L=500$, the error for the classical formula (2) is 0.16224049453604871829 , the error for our formulae (1)-(5) in Theorem 2.3 is 0.0013639041254578376794 , the error for our formulae in Theorem 2.4 is 8.1199227220052350162 $\times 10^{-5}$.

Let $a_{k}^{(0)}(t)$ be the coefficients for the classical formula (2), let $a_{k}^{(1)}(t)$ be the coefficients defined by (1)-(5) in Theorem 2.3, and let $a_{k}^{(2)}(t)$ be the coefficients calculated as in Theorem 2.4.

Figure 1 shows traces of the differences

$$
\widetilde{D}_{k}(t):=a_{k}^{(0)}(t)-a_{k}^{(2)}(t), \quad \bar{D}_{k}(t):=a_{k}^{(0)}(t)-a_{k}^{(1)}(t), \quad D_{k}(t):=a_{k}^{(1)}(t)-a_{k}^{(2)}(t)
$$

for the coefficients $a_{k}(t)$ obtained by three different methods tested above. It can be seen that the differences between the coefficients are small. However, truncated interpolation results are different as was shown above. Also, as expected, the asymptotic behavior of the coefficients $a_{k}(t)$ is different for these three methods. Figure 2 shows the values of the sequences
$L_{k}:=\log \left|a_{k}^{(1)}(t)|k|^{2.49}+1\right|, \quad M_{k}:=\log \left|a_{k}^{(2)}(t)|k|^{2.49}+1\right|, \quad k=-500+\lfloor t\rfloor, \ldots, 500+\lfloor t\rfloor$.
The plot shows that the sequence $M_{k}$ is bounded, which is consistent with the results above implying that $a .(t) \in \rho^{-1} \ell_{\infty}$ with $\alpha<3 / 2$, i.e., that $\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}(1+|k|)^{3 / 2}\left|a_{k}(t)\right|<+\infty$. On the other hand, the sequence $L_{k}$ is unbounded. It can be noted that we used logarithmic functions here to make the trends more visible.

# Discussion and concluding remarks 

1. The classical Whittaker-Shannon-Kotelnikov interpolation formula (2) is applicable to bounded signals vanishing at $t \rightarrow \pm \infty$. Proposition 2.2 covers unbounded signals with growth $\sim|t|^{\alpha}$ for any $\alpha \geq 0$. Theorem 2.3 covers unbounded signals with sublinear growth $\sim|t|^{\alpha}, \alpha \in[0,1 / 2)$. Theorem 2.4 covers unbounded signals with sub-quadratic growth $\sim|t|^{\alpha}, \alpha \in[0,3 / 2)$.
2. For the case where $\alpha<1 / 2$, we have that $\left|a_{k}(t)\right| \sim 1 / k^{2}$ as $|k| \rightarrow+\infty$ and $\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \rho(t)^{-1}\left|a_{k}(t)\right|<+\infty$ for any $t \in \mathbf{R}$. This is why interpolation formula (5) is applicable

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1: The differences $\widetilde{D}_{k}(t), \bar{D}_{k}(t)$, and $D_{k}$, between the coefficients $a_{k}(t)$ used in numerical experiments with $\Omega=5 \pi / 6, t=-1.7$, and $N=6, m=-8$. Here big blue circles are for $\widetilde{D}_{k}(t)$, medium red circles are for $\bar{D}_{k}(t)$, and black dots are for $D_{k}$.
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 2: The sequences $L_{k}(t)=\log \left(|k|^{2.49}\left|a_{k}^{(1)}(t)\right|+1\right)$ (light) and $M_{k}=\log \left(|k|^{2.49}\left|a_{k}^{(2)}(t)\right|+1\right)$ (dark) for the coefficients calculated as in Theorem 2.3 and Theorem 2.4 respectively.

to non-vanishing unbounded signals with moderate growth $\sim|t|^{\alpha}$. For these signals, the classical interpolation formula (2) is not applicable, since its coefficients decay as $\sim 1 / k$.
3. The classical Whittaker-Shannon-Kotelnikov interpolation formula (2) allows spectrum bandwidth $[-\pi, \pi]$. On the other hand, Proposition 2.2 and Theorem 2.3 require that the spectrum bandwidth of $x$ is $[-\Omega, \Omega]$, for $\Omega \in(0, \pi)$. Therefore, the possibility to cover non-decaying unbounded signals is achieved via certain oversampling; this oversampling, however, can be arbitrarily small, since $\Omega$ can be arbitrarily close to $\pi$.
4. The condition that $\Omega \in(0, \pi)$, and that the sampling points are integers, can be removed, as usual, by linear changes of the times scale, i.e., with the replacement of the signal $x(t)$ by signal $x(\mu t)$, with $\mu>0$. Clearly, less frequent sampling would require $\mu>1$, and selection of a larger $\Omega$ would require $\mu<1$.
5. It can be seen that selection of $N$ used for the definition of $g$ in interpolation formula (1)-(5) is non-unique.
6. Different choices of $\left.E(\cdot, \omega)\right|_{|\omega|>\Omega}$ lead to different versions of the interpolation formula.
7. We derived explicitly sampling coefficients $a_{k}(t)$ for the case where $\alpha \in(0,1 / 2)$. For the general case where $\alpha>1 / 2$, one has to select more smooth functions $E(\cdot, \omega)$. Construction of such functions is straightforward, as is shown in Lemma 4.3(B). It is possible to obtain the corresponding coefficients $a_{k}(t)$ explicitely, similarly to the case where $\alpha<1 / 2$. In particular, in the setting of Theorem 2.4 for $\alpha \in[0,3 / 2)$, this would require calculation of integrals of $\omega^{k} e^{-i \omega k}$ for $k=1,2,3$. We leave it for the future research. Alternatively, these $a_{k}(t)$ this can be found via numerical integration; this is how it was done in our numerical examples.
8. It can be emphasised that the interpolation formulae in Theorems 2.3-2.4 are exact;. Therefore, for a vanishing signal $x \in L_{2}(\mathbf{R}) \cap \mathcal{V}(\rho, \Omega)$, all formulae from Theorem 2.3 and Theorem 2.4 give the same value as (2). Similarly, the value is the same when applied for $x \in \mathcal{V}(\rho, \Omega)$ with $a_{k}$ calculated for $\Omega_{0} \in[\Omega, \pi)$ instead of $\Omega$. However, the values for the corresponding finite truncated sums can be different.
9. It can be shown that Proposition 3.4 still holds for $\rho(t)=e^{-\alpha|t|}$ or $\rho(t)=e^{-\alpha t^{2}}$ with $\alpha>0$. However, it does not seem that analogs of Proposition 2.2 or Theorems 2.3-2.4 can

be obtained in this case. This is because all functions $f \in \mathcal{B}(\rho)$ are analytical for these $\rho$, and hence if $f_{\mathbf{R} \backslash D} \equiv 0$ then $f \equiv 0$. This implies that the exponents $e^{i \cdot t}$ do not feature analytical extension from $(-\Omega, \Omega)$ to $\mathbf{R}$ in the space $\rho L_{1}(\mathbf{R})$ with these $\rho$. Moreover, the concept of the spectral gaps in Definition 2.1 is not applicable here; this definition implies that any set $D \subset \mathbf{R}$ with non-empty interior, and such that $D \neq \mathbf{R}$, is a spectrum gap for any signal from $\rho^{-1} L_{\infty}(\mathbf{R})$ with these $\rho$.

abstract:
The paper establishes an analog Whittaker-Shannon-Kotelnikov sampling theorem
for unbounded non-decaying band-limited signals. An explicit interpolation
formula is obtained for signals sublinear growth with rate of growth less than
1/2. At any time, the rate of decay for the $k$th coefficients of this formula
is $\sim 1/k^2$. In addition, the paper obtains a method for calculating the
coefficients of the interpolation formula applicable to signals with
arbitrarily high rate of polynomial growth.
